The first BioShock is one of the best games of all time (with the exception of the Single Player of BioShock 2, the franchise is GROUDBREAKING) BioShock Infinite is a solid title as well.

Infinite suprised me. It was far better than I predicted it would have been when the first trailer was released. Most of that has to do woth BioShock Infinite being developed by the original development team (2k Marrin made BioShock 2's campaign) 2k Boston & 2k Australia, now Irrational, which they were originally called, so the name change proved to be rather pointless.

The setting of Infinite is, in one word, ASTOUNDING. Sure, it could have been better, but still amazing. Whenever I first saw Columbia, the floating city that this game takes place in, my jaw hit the floor. For real, no joke.
The game takes place in 1912, you are hired gun Booker DeWitt, a war veteran. Your objective, to rescue a girl named Ellizabeth from Columbia. The story is really good in this game, and gets really interesting at the end, but every now and then it gets confusing.  If you forget where mto go, just press 'N' and a green arrow will appear on the ground.

In this BioShock, you can only hold 2 weapons at a time, and use 2 vigors, which do the EXACT same thing plasmids do. Vigors you cn swap anytime by holding down 'Q', but weapons you do not,  you go around and pick them up, obviously. There are 2 interesting vigors in this game: Return to Sender and the Bucking Bronco. Bucking Bronco launches your enemies into the air and caused them to float for a brief period of time. Return to Sender allows you to block bullets and rockets. You can also throw the 'orb' that collects them at enemies.
Devil's Kiss (which replaces Incinerate!) is only good at close range. I mainly use it to take out large groups of enemies.
Shock Jocky is the new Electro-bolt, and pretty useful against weaker enemies and enemies at long range (especially those douchebags with grenade launchers) because it stuns them for a few seconds.
There are more vigors, but these are the most important.
The gameplay is changed, but at the same time similar. Instead of guns kicking up, your guns now have changing crosshairs, like in Halo Reach. Instead of having different types of ammo, you have 2 choices of every type of gun except for the RPG and the sniper rifle. You have the Vox Populi set of weapons, which are more powerful, but have tweaks to them that make them balanced so they don't make the game to easy, and the standard Comstock issued weapons, 

Elizabeth plays a BIG role in Infinite, and is very helpful. She wil throw ammo to you when you get low, health, and money when you go near a vending machine. She also throws salts (which is the new name for EVE) when you run out every now and then. Don't worry, this doesn't make the game easy. It works really well in the end. If she didn't do this, you would be running out of ammo all of the time and dying a lot.

She can also do other useful things, like open up tears in combat, which gives you access to turrets, cover, rockets, guns, salts, and health kits.


There is no multiplayer mode, but there is a ton of replay value. You will find hidden areas that you missed during other playthroughs. The game was made to be played more than one time.

This game gets a 9.6/10 for gameplay, but gets a 10/10 overall. The story, setting, and the cool things that Elizabeth does adds a lot to the final package. As soon as I beat this game, I wanted to play it again. that tells a lot about how good this game is.

But, it is still far behind the first BioShock.

I'm not entirely sure where to start with this review of Bioshock Infinite. At time of writing (around 10 hours after the UK release on March 26th 2013), I finished the 8+ hour campaign in a single sitting around 2-3 hours ago after no sleep and I'm still trying to mentally process the experience in order to evaluate it. While this might not immediately sound like the best mindset to have when trying to writing a review, I felt now is the best time as this post-game mindset perfectly reflects my feelings towards Bioshock Infinite as a game: breathtaking, awe inspiring, thought provoking, complex, deep and utterly brilliant. 

Ken Levine and the team at Irrational Games have outdone themselves once again by creating yet another extremely inventive, inspired and interesting game world inhabited by intriguing and believable characters. As hard as this may be to swallow for some players, Columbia and it's inhabitants are far more developed and enjoyable to spend time around than Rapture, to the point where standing and watching the city folk go about their lives becomes an immersive highlight of the game. The arrival of a wide variety of interesting and developed characters such as Booker, Elizabeth, Comstock and Fitzroy is extremely welcome as the brilliant acting and stellar writing from the first game once again return, just with a much greater focus on personal character development this time around. 

If, for some weird reason, you're still on the fence about whether or not to buy Bioshock Infinite, look at it this way. If you're looking for a deeply engrossing and immersive game world with astonishing visual design, fast paced inventive gameplay or an emotionally driven and complex storyline, look no further. While the game would've already been fantastic if it had merely replicated Bioshock 1, additional innovative design elements such as the social/religious/racial commentaries push the game that much further as a powerfully moving and artistic interactive experience, making them the added seasoning which makes Bioshock Infinite one of those few astonishingly high quality games that nobody should miss.

Bioshock Infinite is like a weird circus show your friend performs for you. First, they juggle a bit. Then they ride the unicycle. Then they do both at once. Oh and they sing a song you like. Pretty cool, huh? Suddenly, the guy jumps off the unicycle and pulls the carpet from under you. You hit your head on the ground. The performance was about the carpet the whole time! Isn't it intellectually challenging and great?

The gameplay is rather enjoyable, in my opinion. Guns are fun, enemies are challenging, Sky-Hooks are interesting. Some of the tougher enemies encourage cheap tactics, though. Yet the game is hard to put down, partly because the auto-saves are so sneaky. There's never a clear pause that makes you look at the clock. Oops!

Bioshock Infinite is a significant game and you should play it to learn something about modern storytelling. I don't know if it's good, but it's definitely significant.

Bioshock infinite c'est bien plus que Raputure dans le ciel. Ce jeu est une exprience à vivre, notamment  pour Elisabeth l'un des meilleurs persos de jeux vidéos crée, une histoire de malade, et de loin le meilleur épisode de la série.

Disons le clairement : je n'ai pas aimé le premier Bioshock (oui je suis une espèce rare). Le principe du gameplay était très intéressant mais son univers m'a laissé de marbre et même déplu à tel point que je ne l'ai jamais fini.
Maintenant conservons le gameplay mais changeons totalement de décor pour une superbe ville dans les nuages, une Bespin du début du XXème siècle. C'est vivant et c'est surtout magnifique de beauté, chaque parcelle de la ville vient vous chatouiller la rétine et on se surprend à s'arrêter de jouer pour contempler le paysage et prendre des screenshots, tel un touriste visitant Venise.
L'univers entier nous happe dès les premières minutes de jeu. C'est prenant et le scénario brille par son originalité. En ce sens, Bioshock Infinite a des qualités cinématographiques indéniables.
On se délecte de lancer sur ses ennemis des hordes de corbeaux leur dévorant la chair avant de les envoyer voltiger dans les airs puis les brûler par la flamme qui s'échappe de nos mains.
Et que dire de notre partenaire, la belle Elizabeth. Très bien doublée (en tout cas en VO), expressive, voilà enfin et surtout une héroine qui ne nous tape pas sur les nerfs au bout de 5 minutes et ne nous encombre pas de son incompétence. Au contraire ! Elle nous aide durant les combats en nous lançant des armes ou des munitions et nous soigne.
Vous l'aurez compris, je suis conquis !
Inconstablement le meilleur jeu 2013 sorti jusque là et probablement le meilleur de l'année (Rome Total War 2 ?).
Sur ce je vous laisse, j'y retourne ;)

Bioshock Infinite is one of the best FPS I have ever played and the first one that made me feel and think all the time. Its world, characters and story are deep and diverse, the artdesign is not from this world. It floats among the clouds like the city of Columbia.
Columbia itself, the perfect city in the sky, is one of two main "characters" of the game. The leveldesign is fantastic, the artdesign is nearly perfect. It´s vast and detailed and you can just stand their for a  time just... experiencing beauty. It´s like a picture, a piece of wonder.
The best original city in gaming in a long time.
The second main character of Bioshock is not the game´s protagonist, Booker DeWitt, former cavalry officer and Pinkerton detective, but his protégé and companion, Elizabeth, both the best AI companion in any game I have ever played and one of the best female characters in gaming. She is well acted, well written, doesn´t get stuck or in the way (thank god), is more than important for the game´s twisted, confusing (but in the end fantastic) plot, which I won´t spoil and is a perfect  "supporting" character both in a gameplay and a storytelling sense.
The gameplay is frantic and fun, the difficulty is hard enough without being too frustrating (not talking about 1999 of course) and the vigors (secondary special attacks like telekinisis and fireballs, to name the two most ordinary) are a nice change to the (extremly cool looking) weaponry in the game.
The only real downgrading elements are the game´s AI and campaign length, the latter is just disappointing because i just wanted it to be infinite.But the enemies who are quite diverse and have to be fought in different styles are sometimes like zombies or, more fitting, like Splicers without masks. Well some wear masks.
In the end it must be said that Bioshock Infinite is one of the most gorgeous and deep FPS ever, its story is a twisted thrill and Elizabeth is my favourite NPC next to Clementine and the Mass Effect crew.
9/10 Points for Bioshock Infinite

With Bioshock Infinite I decided to take a huge leap of faith, unusual to me, and called it a masterpiece long before its release.Comes the actual game and I found I was quite right.

The main points of Bioshock Infinite are the artistic design and the plot. On this note, the title was delayed three times, and now we know why. Suffice to say, without spoiling anything, that the Ken Levine and the other developers swifted the main focus of the game from a political plot to a quantistic, other-worlds shenanigans tale. So, expect every promotional or pre-release material about Bioshock Infinite to have been either dummied out or reduced to foot notes. Someone, like me, thinks this was an improvement, given how the final product has turned out. Others, less so.

What remained beside all of this is the great level and character design. Beside the main concept of Columbia, the world and its inhabitants have been designed to a maniacal level. Quite fitting, since Bioshock Infinite wanted to melt with real history, imaginery and art. Of course, this could be due to me being a steampunk affictionado.

The weakest aspect of Bioshock Infinite is aguably the gameplay. In the measure that the game is far too easy, even for the Bioshock series standards. Death is a mere slap on the wrist: it will merely consume some of your money and you can get back on your feeth, with some ammo too. And unless you play 1999 Mode, reaching zero dollars doesn't prevent you to respawn. The Vigors, the resident magical powers, are just a mean to end battles quickly, instead of a core mechanic. Some gears (as to say, additional gimmicks you can equip the protagonist with) are game-breaking. Many battles are endurance rounds instead of death traps. All the above considered, you should start the game on hard mode, and then give the 1999 Mode difficulty a go. Things tend to go greasy in there.

All of that said, Bioshock Infinite is competing with American McGee's Alice for the place of my best game ever. A nice accomplishment.

Добрый принц на белом коне врывается в замок и спасает принцессу, но не тут-то было. Сам принц совсем не добрый и посему задолжал местным барыгам, которые заставили его выкрасть девчонку и привести к ним. Элизабет видимо совсем обречена, если ведется на поводу незнакомца зная то, что её ведут на выкуп. При том постоянно мешается под ногами, хваленый искуственный интеллект девки явно оказался пустышкой. Её ценность в игре крайне сомнительна, как и бредовость самого сюжета, а самое страшное то, что в игре нет атмосферы. Ведь в первой части она была уже в меню, там мы искали автоматы по усовершенствованию оружия и с кайфом не могли насмотреться на изменившийся не только внешне ствол, причём каждый агрегат был по своему нужен и уникален. Здесь можно пройти игру с винтарём и крысятиной, попутно прицеливаяь и дорезая ножом как в Call of Duty, механика тут явно из этой серии игр. Биотики впринципе бесполезны и нужна только пиромантия, а сам летающий город по сути не интересен и укомплектован одинаковыми НеПиСями и несколькими штуками врагов. Кинцо на одноразовый просмотр и забытие.

A man is taken to hunt for girl and discovers a far more complex plot.

A first person adventure game relying heavily on action. It features a similar drug induced power system as the predecssors, fast paced combat, a utopian location that isn't as perfect as one may believe and a single, unkillable(?) male hero. However, this is where the similairties stop.

The basic story premise is one about time travel and choice.
One person's choice created a split of possibilities. Personal bias aside, this game has many contradictions to itself. On one hand we discover something is possible, on the other it isn't because of other examples of happenings.
The main aspect this game strives for is the confusing story it tries to convey, but doesn't do it very well. If you can find a way to ignore the contradictions, it can make sense, although ignoring the contradictions leaves a lot out of the game's story.

Bioshock Infinite exceeds its illustrious predecessors and lives up to the ridiculous hype and universal praise that it's received; in fact, it is *the best* game of this "generation"... and that is saying something considering the sheer number of classics that have been released in the last decade.

Bioshock Infinite is a genuine piece of art - every aspect is executed to the highest possible standard, from the artistic presentation (somehow steampunk and dreamlike at the same time... not a common combination) to the fast paced and creativity focused combat, to the mind bending plot... but the superb fundamentals are only part of the package. Every aspect of the game is drenched in commentary, character development, and the type of thematic challenges one expects from only the very best "hard" science fiction. There's more to ponder and enjoy in a single nook of one level than has been served up in the entire Call of Duty series.

Bioshock Infinite is exhilarating, and heartbreaking, and generally worthwhile in a way that most pop culture artifacts no longer even consider attempting. You *must* play this game.

This could only be my reasoning, but in comparison to previous intents of having Elizabeth participate further in the enviornment, with discussions with Booker, and in combat, as well as further expanding skyline concepts and vigor variety, the combat serves as a con that seems more as filler to push along the game than should be, and previous drafts of the game serve to be an example of what Infinite could be. Even with all of these complaints though, I enjoyed it despite its dragging in certain acts. It has incredible high points, some notable low points, but its a solid experience all in all. Bioshock: Infinite launches you into the floating city of Columbia, a floating city of American ideals. You play as Booker DeWitt, an ex-Pinkerton agent sent to repay his debt from gambling by retrieving a woman named Elizabeth.

From the get-go, your intial launch into Columbia in nothing less than absolutely stunning. From the vibrant and beautiful colour palettes to the bright sunny skies that illuminate the city strees, Columbia is gorgeous to look at. Each and every part of it has been painted with such precise details and the citizens make effort to give breathing life to the imaginative world. You'll often find yourself staring off into the skies aweing or just absorbing the history the world has to offer. 

Of course, for the masterful piece of artwork it is, it is also a video game! The combat gameplay is solid and smooth. Much like the previous titles, you have access to both guns and vigors (the replacement for plasmids). There's plenty of freedom to create your own violent method of dispatching your enemies by  stringing vigors and weapon combos together. However, one of the best parts about the gameplay is the sky-lines, a rollercoaster speed trip through the skies of Columbia. There's plenty of large sky-lines to sail across, and the tight controls allow you to gracefully glide around and plan your enemies' deaths with guerilla tactics. You can also upgrade your combat abillities by purchasing upgrades from vendors and finding gear (which are equipment items that increase a certain skill). 

However, one of the most amazing aspect of the game is Elizabeth, a wonderous emotional character whom partners with you on your journey. Her body movements and expressions are amazing, showing emotion and thought with great execution. She's an easily likable character and you won't ever feel like she's some AI partner who assist you, but something more human. During combat, she will provide you ammo, health, and salts; although, it'll never feel like she's making the game to easy for you, and when she's gone, you'll probably miss her. 

The story itself is thought-provoking and filled with many controversial topics, but never will tell you which one thing is right and wrong, but leaving it up to you as a player to decide which is morally correct. It starts out simple and gets increasingly more complex as you progress; closing it all with one of the best finales I've seen in a while. 

There is some gripes I have with the game, although they are just minor. You're only limited to two weapons at a time, and often find yourself sticking to your upgraded weapon for most of the playthough. On a playthough on Hard or 1999 Mode, the game sometimes becomes a scavenger hunt for your best weapons because there is no machine that lets you purchase the gun itself, but rather just upgrade them. Another minor annoyance, is during tense combat fights, trying to pick up another weapon, can end up looting the body instead and not picking up the gun (as they are both binded to the USE key). 

Bioshock: Infinite is a imaginative, story-driven, solid shooter that will leaving a lasting impression on your mind. One that will fill your heart with amazement, confusion, and morale. From it's gorgeous opening to it's amazing last moments, you won't regret your purchase. This game is.. *puts on sunglasses* sky high brilliant.
